node.title: Russia's supply of key metals causes price surges
node.description: The Russian attack on Ukraine is causing major disruptions to the global metals market and is pushing up the costs for local businesses in the process.

node.title: 'There's just so much damage': Auckland store ram-raided before it flooded
node.description: Hundreds of Aucklanders are grappling with soggy, smelly and expensive repair work after heavy rain this week, with one store left vunerable after robbers ram-raided it hours before the deluge.

node.title: Deadly tornado tears through New Orleans area
node.description: It took at least one person life. The storm system then moved toward other parts of the Deep South. It had killed someone in Texas the day before.

node.title: Households facing $150 a week extra in inflation costs, says bank
node.description: High inflation and rising interest rates will cost households an average $150 a week extra, according to ASB Bank.

node.title: 'It's nonsensical': Businesses lukewarm on some Covid-19 changes
node.description: Hospitality businesses are upset that the government's relaxation of health measures does not go far enough.

node.title: Covid-19 update: 20,087 new cases, death toll rises above 200
node.description: New Zealand's total death toll of people with Covid-19 has now grown to more than 200, with 11 new deaths announced today, as well as 20,087 new community cases.

node.title: Food banks are a godsend, but one charity believes there’s a better way
node.description: Food banks are under more pressure than ever due to the cost of living, but one South Auckland social service questions whether they're the only way to help.

node.title: How important is NZ's new military support for Ukraine?
node.description: International analyst Geoffrey Miller examines New Zealand's new military assistance for Ukraine and asks whether more humanitarian aid could also be provided.

node.title: How hairy dairy cows turned out to be pretty cool for scientists
node.description: Country Life: The unfortunate arrival of some particularly hairy dairy cows has led to the discovery of a gene that could make the national herd better able to tolerate hot summer days. Audio

node.title: Omicron: 'Major impact' on staff shortages as apple picking season peaks
node.description: It is peak apple harvest time across the country - and Omicron is not showing any signs of slowing down in the two busiest apple harvest regions - Hawke's Bay and Nelson-Tasman.

node.title: Air New Zealand sets sights on New York
node.description: The airline will start direct flights to New York City later this year as it looks to recover from the financial impact of Covid-19.

node.title: Search and rescue after China's first plane crash since 2010
node.description: Rescuers have kept up their search for survivors in the heavily forested mountains of China's southern Guangxi region, with Chinese state media describing the situation as "grim".

node.title: Ash Barty, world's top-ranked women's tennis player, announces retirement at age 25
node.description: Barty had won 25 of her last 26 matches and three of her past four events, including the Australian Open in January.

node.title: Kathmandu reports loss due to Covid-19 lockdown disruptions and higher costs
node.description: The outdoor goods and clothing company has fallen to a first half loss as Covid-related disruptions and higher operating expenses eroded margins and restrained sales.

node.title: Speed limit for Motueka's High Street changes to 30km
node.description: The speed limit through Motueka's town centre on High Street will be reduced to 30 kilometres per hour.

node.title: Heavyweight world champ given persmission to leave Ukraine
node.description: Ukraine's heavyweight boxing world champion Oleksandr Usyk will prepare for his rematch with Briton Anthony Joshua, after getting permission to leave his country and train ESPN has reported.

node.title: Dismantling the internet: Digital iron curtain descends on Russia
node.description: A digital iron curtain is falling on Russia as the government increases censorship and foreign companies withdraw services. Audio

node.title: Lanning leads Australia to another win
node.description: Australia's relentless march through the World Cup continued with captain Meg Lanning thrashing an unbeaten century as they beat South Africa by five-wickets.

node.title: What you need to know: Key changes for scanning, vaccine passes and mandates
node.description: Explainer - The country's public health restrictions are being adjusted with scanning, vaccine passes and mandates on the way out.

node.title: Covid-19: Vaccine passes, some mandates and outdoor gathering limit to be removed - PM
node.description: All outdoor gathering limits will be removed from the traffic light system, indoor gathering limits will increase and vaccine passes will no longer be required, Jacinda Ardern has announced.

node.title: What's causing this heavy rain? 'Clearly global warming is in the mix'
node.description: A climate scientist says climate change and long-term weather systems are behind the recent extreme flooding in the country - including the ravaged Tairāwhiti Gisborne.

node.title: "March Madness" banners at women's NCAA tournament are a sign of change
node.description: For years, post-season play for the national women's title has been called the "NCAA Women's Tournament," while the men's playoff bracket is widely promoted simply as the iconic "March Madness" tournament.

node.title: Warehouse Group keen to compete with supermarket chains
node.description: The Warehouse Group says it would be "very happy" to fully compete with the big two grocery chains that dominate the New Zealand market, providing measures are put in place to ensure a level playing…

node.title: Fisher & Paykel Healthcare forecasts drop on 2021 record revenue
node.description: A lower number of respiratory interventions needed for the Omicron variant is among factors affecting Fisher & Paykel Healthcare's bottom line.

node.title: Special election set for June to fill seat of late Congressman Don Young
node.description: The election will be the state's first full test of its new voting system. Sarah Palin is mulling an entry into the race.

node.title: Computer chip shortage expected to last till mid-2023
node.description: A global shortage of computer chips is likely to persist for another 18 months, according to an Australasian manufacturing business.

node.title: Inquiry under way into Far North fishing boat tragedy
node.description: An investigation into how a fishing boat capsized off North Cape, killing five people, is about safety not apportioning blame, the chief investigator says. Audio

node.title: Chris Wood leads All Whites to win over Fiji
node.description: Chris Wood made history as the All Whites beat Fiji 4-0 in their second group game at the Oceania World Cup qualifying tournament in Qatar.

node.title: Police who killed were given evidence in advance
node.description: When police shoot and kill, they're investigated by fellow officers. Guyon Espiner reveals that shooters have been shown evidence in advance of being interviewed.

node.title: 85-year-old Detroit artist and former teacher sees childhood dream come true
node.description: Her exhibit, titled the "Shield of the Nile Reflections," is running for the first time at the Detroit Institute of Arts through June 12, 2022.
